question: Will the debt ceiling be raised or suspended in the US before March 17, 2025?
description:
*This question is part of the* [*Bridgewater Forecasting Contest*](https://www.metaculus.com/bridgewater/)*. To be eligible to win prizes in the competition you must register for the tournament. The last day to register is March 24, 2025. Sign up or check your registration status* [*here*](https://www.metaculus.com/bridgewater/)*.*

***

The [debt limit](https://www.crfb.org/papers/qa-everything-you-should-know-about-debt-ceiling) or debt ceiling in the United States, first established in 1917, sets a limit on the amount of money the US Treasury can borrow. As the US typically borrows to pay prior obligations, reaching the debt limit also limits the ability of the Treasury to fulfill debt obligations, risking default. When the debt limit is reached the Treasury will typically undertake [extraordinary measures](https://www.crfb.org/papers/qa-everything-you-should-know-about-debt-ceiling#what_are_extraordinary_measures) to avoid default as long as possible.

The debt ceiling was last suspended in June 2023, but the suspension [expired in January 2025](https://www.cnn.com/2025/01/17/business/debt-ceiling-limit-congress/index.html). On January 17, outgoing Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen [notified Congress](https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy2798) that the Treasury had begun taking extraordinary measures to avoid default, including implementing a "debt issuance suspension period" on certain funds the government typically invests. This suspension period was specified to persist through March 14, 2025.

[According to the Peter G. Peterson Foundation](https://www.pgpf.org/article/the-debt-ceiling-will-be-reinstated-on-january-1-heres-whats-at-stake/):

> The extraordinary measures and cash balance typically can last up to a few months. Most recently, extraordinary measures enabled the government to continue meeting its obligations from January 2023 until lawmakers suspended the debt ceiling in June 2023 as part of the [Fiscal Responsibility Act](https://www.congress.gov/bill/118th-congress/house-bill/3746).
>  
> If the available options are exhausted prior to legislation being enacted to adjust the debt ceiling, the United States would default on its debt.

The brinkmanship involved in the 2023 debt ceiling suspension was a contributing factor to the US' credit rating being [downgraded](https://www.pgpf.org/article/moodys-lowers-us-credit-rating-to-negative-citing-large-federal-deficits/) by two credit agencies, Fitch and Moody's, later in 2023.

Reaching an agreement to raise or suspend the debt ceiling [could be difficult](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/congress/gop-ponders-raise-debt-ceiling-dozens-members-ve-always-held-rcna188824) for President Trump and Congress due to the Republicans' thin majority in the House of Representatives.

For additional resources, see a [tracker of the historical debt limit and debt subject to limit](https://www.ryanbeckauthor.com/forecasting/DebtLimit.html) and the Congressional Research Service report [*Debt Limit Policy Questions: How Long Do Extraordinary Measures Last?*](https://crsreports.congress.gov/product/pdf/IN/IN12147)
fine_print:
* Any amount of increase to the debt limit qualifies.
* Only an enacted law is sufficient. Attempts to increase, suspend, or abolish the debt limit by other means, such as by executive order, are immaterial.

**US Debt Crisis Looms in 2025: $9.2 Trillion of Debt Matures, Putting Pressure on Financial Markets**
The United States' national debt of $36.2 trillion will reach a critical point in 2025, with $9.2 trillion of debt maturing, representing 25.4% of the country's total debt. This has raised concerns about its implications on financial markets, interest rates, and economic stability. The rapid accumulation of debt has been driven by historically high levels of deficit spending, with a $13 trillion increase since 2020, averaging $2.6 trillion annually over the past five years. The federal deficit for 2024 is $1.8 trillion, equivalent to 6.4% of GDP, and interest payments on the debt have increased to over $1 trillion annually. The situation is alarming, with 70% of the maturing debt, or $6.5 trillion, due between January and June 2025, putting significant pressure on bond markets. The government will be forced to issue a large amount of new bonds to meet these maturities, increasing the supply of Treasury bonds and potentially driving up yields. The market has already shown signs of tension, with real yields increasing steadily since 2022. The 10-year Treasury yield has risen 115 basis points since the start of rate cuts, reflecting investors' growing concern about the government's increasing debt. As The Kobeissi Letter noted on February 4, 'the problem of US debt is not new, but the magnitude of the refinancing challenge in 2025 makes it a topic that investors cannot ignore.'

**US Treasury Releases First Debt Financing Plan Under Deese, Maintains Yellen's Policy Language**
US Treasury Secretary Brian Deese has released the country's first debt financing plan since taking office, despite his previous criticism of Janet Yellen's debt strategy. The plan maintains the same debt structure and pace as Yellen's, which has eased concerns in the US debt market. As of the release, yields on various US debt terms have fallen, with the 10-year Treasury yield dropping nearly 8 basis points to 4.43%, a new low since December last year. This decline in yields means bond prices have risen. The US dollar has weakened, and COMEX gold has continued to rise 1%, pushing its historical high to $2900 per ounce. The US Treasury has announced that it will auction off $1.25 trillion in debt next week to pay off $1.06 trillion in maturing debt, with specific terms including: $580 billion in 3-year notes due on February 15, 2028; $420 billion in 10-year notes due on February 15, 2035; and $250 billion in 30-year notes due on February 15, 2055. The most notable phrase in the Treasury's statement is the continued mention of 'expecting to continue to maintain nominal coupon and floating rate note auction sizes in the coming quarters.' This phrase has been present since the US increased its debt auction size in early 2024, but was previously criticized by Deese and some Republicans as a way to artificially lower long-term borrowing rates before the election. The Treasury's Borrowing Advisory Committee has encouraged the Treasury to consider canceling or modifying the forward guidance on debt auction sizes, with some members advocating for its complete removal and others suggesting a more toned-down language. However, at least for now, Deese has decided to continue using Yellen's policy language. The focus behind this phrase is the speculation that the US will continue to increase its debt issuance. Given the US government's long-term fiscal deficit, traders widely expect Deese to decide to issue more long-term US debt at some point, with speculation pointing to a time frame between August this year and next year. The Treasury has also stated that it will use short-term Treasury bills with a maturity of up to one year to meet any seasonal or unexpected borrowing needs over the next three months. Since the US debt ceiling has been restarted since the beginning of this year, the Treasury has taken extraordinary measures to avoid violating the ceiling. The department has also stated: 'Before the debt ceiling is suspended or raised, debt ceiling-related restrictions will cause the volatility of bond issuance to be greater than normal levels and significantly use cash management bonds.' For Deese, another uncertainty in measuring debt issuance demand is when the Federal Reserve will end its quantitative tightening. Currently, the Fed sells $250 billion in US debt to the market each month, so ending quantitative tightening will reduce the Treasury's debt issuance demand. The advisory committee now believes that the Fed's quantitative tightening will end in the summer, with a risk that the end date will be later.

**U.S. Treasury to Issue First Benchmark 6-Week Treasury Bill Amid**
The U.S. Treasury Department plans to issue its first benchmark 6-week Treasury bill, marking a transition from regular 6-week cash management bills. However, the Treasury has highlighted that until the debt ceiling is suspended or raised, there will be significant volatility in the issuance of benchmark Treasury bills. This reflects the constraints imposed by the debt limit. The Treasury had previously announced its intention to transform the regular 6-week cash management bills into a benchmark product, integrating it into the regular issuance schedule, as part of ongoing discussions since 2020.

**US Treasury to Maintain Auction Sizes, Gradually Increase TIPS Auctions**
The US Department of the Treasury announced that it will maintain the sizes of its coupon and floating-rate note auctions in the next quarters, but will continue to gradually increase the size of its Treasury Inflation-Protected Securities (TIPS) auctions. The Treasury said it will increase the reopening of 10-year TIPS in March by $1 billion, to $18 billion, and will increase the new issuance auction of 5-year TIPS in April to $25 billion. The department also plans to sell $125 billion in its quarterly refunding next week, raising $18.8 billion in new cash and refunding $106.2 billion in securities, including $58 billion in 3-year notes, $42 billion in 10-year notes, and $25 billion in 30-year notes. The Treasury also noted that there will be 'a greater variability than normal in the issuance of reference notes and a significant use' of cash management notes until the US debt ceiling is increased or suspended. The Treasury expects to resume cash management note repurchases around the April 2025 fiscal date, in addition to planned liquidity support repurchases.

**US Treasury Implements Emergency Measures to Avoid Default**
The US Department of the Treasury has begun implementing emergency measures to avoid a default on its internal debt obligations. According to a letter from former Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen, these measures were put in place on January 21, 2025, as the US has reached its maximum allowed level of government debt. The Treasury Department is forced to implement a set of tools that reduce internal spending and redirect payments to service the national debt, including interest payments. The first of these tools is the reduction of investments in the Civil Service Retirement Fund and the Postal Service Health Benefits Fund. Further measures to reduce spending will be implemented by the Treasury Department in a step-by-step manner and may remain in effect until March 14, 2025, until the threat of default is avoided. The current level of US government debt is estimated at $36.197 trillion, according to the US Treasury Department's data as of January 16. The US temporarily suspended the debt ceiling in June 2023, when former President Joe Biden signed a deal with Congress, freeing himself from the need to raise the borrowing limit until January 2, 2025. The new debt ceiling is equivalent to the amount of unpaid debt at the end of the previous day. According to Treasury Department data, this figure was over $36.218 trillion as of December 31. In December, before taking office, former President Donald Trump demanded that his Republican colleagues repeal the debt ceiling before his return to the White House, but this was not done. As a result, the executive and legislative branches of the US government will have to return to this issue in January. The growing national debt is further complicated for Washington by the growing costs of paying interest on it. According to Treasury Department calculations, the US government paid over $1 trillion in interest on its national debt in 2024, a first in its history. The volume of spending on these purposes will continue to grow, further depriving the government of funds for economic development and pushing it deeper into debt.

However, this would delay the resolution of issues such as disaster relief until 2025, which Goldman Sachs believes would not be acceptable to either side. The debt ceiling is also a point of contention. Although the debt ceiling suspension expires on January 2, 2025, the Treasury is likely to continue borrowing until the third quarter of 2025. Analysts consider this to reduce the need for immediate action, but Trump's attention to this issue suggests it may return to the agenda in early 2025. Goldman Sachs estimates that each week of government shutdown would reduce quarterly GDP growth by 0.15%, with an equivalent bounce-back after the government resumes work. While a short-term shutdown is possible, analysts consider a prolonged impasse unlikely.
